title: Can the thoughts of one person significantly alter the collective consciousness? - Quora

response.answer_text: Religious leaders e.g. Christ, Gandhi, Buddha, et al., authors, inventors, scientists, artists, composers, performers, national leaders, political commentators and columnists, marketers and their adverts, and many others, can significantly alter the collective consciousness. Here’s a blast from the past by JFK targeted here at Grades 3–6, with thought questions planting a seed for lifelong and even multi-generational applications: "Ask not what your country can do for you..." Can YOU, questioner, significantly alter the collective consciousness? I don’t know. Maybe. Or maybe in union with a critical mass of others of like mind. Show us what you’ve got! Let the cynics wish they had come up with your idea.

Of course, but this is totally unremarkable. “Collective consciousness” is purely a metaphor. It’s not a real thing. At best, it describes something more like zeitgeist. It’s not consciousess, just that there is a set of ideas that are commonly held. Totally passive, which contradicts the defining characteristic of a consciousness (which is activity). It’s just new-age woo to imagine that there is some kind of ongoing “consciousness field” that everyone’s thoughts are connected to (the physics of this are laughable!) So lots of famous meme contributors have significantly altered the collective zeitgeist, in fields like science and religion (and perhaps music, painting, etc).

There is no such thing as “collective consciousness”, and nobody’s thoughts affect anyone else. This kind of “New Age Woo-woo” is just superstition. There are certainly shared beliefs — i.e. many people believe the same things — and common interpretations, where many people use similar interpretive schema that are socially constructed and exchanged in culturally-relative ways. But it’s a mistake to think that the phrase “collective consciousness” is meaningful as something more than a metaphor. We’ve left the Dark Ages, when everyone believed superstitions. Let’s keep walking.

Yes, and this is actually a very scary, daunting notion we instinctively try to block out right now, as we simply have no education, preparation to handle such vast, crushing responsibility. But we won't have a choice but to investigate and understand what actually it means that we have evolved into a single, closed, fully integrated and interdependent system, where the so-called “butterfly effect” world with full force. And since thoughts, intentions represent the most powerful forces in reality - which we know with the help of quantum physics - with every thought, intention we influence the whole system! And since inherently we make calculations decisions in a self-serving, subjective manner, we intend only for our own sake, we are by default constantly harming everything and anybody around us all over the world! Thus it is not surprising that our world is in a terrible crisis, chaos. So we urgently need the right, purposeful and practical educational method to help us adjust, adapt ourselves to the integral system so so the influence, interference we “broadcast”, project would become positive, constructive got the whole system. The Butterfly Effect Is Strongest On The Level Of Thought | Laitman.com Ynet: “What Is The Hidden Law Of Nature?” | Laitman.com

Thoughts will have no direct effect anyway because the collective Unconscious was likened to the “Sea” by Jung - with our Personal Unconscious being like an “iceberg”. The Collective Unconscious therefore relates more to the FEELING - OR EMOTIONAL dimension of life. Jung answered this question when he was asked about whether or not people could control their dreams. He said that, in his experience, it was like “handling an unruly dog” - if we saw it sitting we would say “sit” ………… and so on. Absolutely not!!! We live in a world where each must find their own way. This is why “Group Think” is so dangerous. if this question was to help you — then live by this motto… “QUESTION ABSOLUTELY EVERY SINGLE THING IN LIFE!!!”
There is no such thing as ‘the collective consciousness’ other than as a broad metaphor for what otherwise might be described as ‘culture’ or ‘the zeitgeist’. So no.
